Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Summer Research Experience for Undergraduates in Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: This is a ten-week summer residential research participation experience that engages undergraduate students in full-time active research collaborations with faculty, research professionals, and graduate students at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. A selection of research projects in Physics and Applied Physics spanning from energy applications to fundamental science is provided. In addition to their own research area, students will be exposed to a variety of research topics and methodologies through regular research seminars and student presentations. Further breadth will be developed through visits to nearby research facilities. Students will gain experience in presenting their results by making oral and written presentations throughout the summer. This project impacts the research and development competitiveness of the United States by recruiting excellent students into STEM research fields and by training these students to perform leading-edge research in technologically important fields.

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: This is a ten-week summer residential research participation experience that engages undergraduate students in full-time active research collaborations with faculty, research professionals, and graduate students at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. Undergraduate students are both mentored individually by research faculty and engage in group professional development activities. Research projects are cutting-edge in Physics and Applied Physics and include particle and galactic astrophysics, computational physics, nano- and low-dimensional materials, photonics and ultrafast optics, geophysics, complex systems, educational physics, and the chemistry, optoelectronics, and physics of solar energy conversion. In addition to their own research area, students will be exposed to a variety of research topics and methodologies through a series of research seminars and student presentations. Further breadth will be developed through visits to nearby research facilities. To assist in their professional development, students also participate in tutorials on ethics, applying to graduate school, scientific writing and giving scientific presentations. Students gain experience in presenting their results by making oral and written presentations throughout the summer. This project impacts the research and development competitiveness of the United States by recruiting excellent students into STEM research fields and by training these students to perform leading-edge research in technologically important fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Rensselaer Physics REU site is focused on engaging students in intensive, timely and compelling interdisciplinary research projects in Physics, Applied Physics and Astronomy that can inspire them to pursue careers in these fields. The intellectual core of the research projects span areas in condensed matter physics, computational physics, astrophysics, astronomy, particle physics, biophysics, geophysics, energy conversion, and complex systems and networks. The REU features hands-on research projects guided by experienced faculty to provide the students with an opportunity to participate in work that can result in publications and develop professional skills. 
Goals for each REU term include the following.  i) Students should gain significant knowledge of a new scientific discipline and the tools to do original work. ii) Students should learn about the depth and breadth of work that is necessary to produce new knowledge at the cutting edge of science and technology by directly participating in the work. Participating students should develop a better understanding of how a research project is conceived, designed, executed and effectively communicated through direct experience. iii) Students should develop the ability to clearly communicate the results and implications of their work. iv) Students should learn to work productively in a team.
Outcomes for each of the four areas are assessed using several measures. Students are surveyed and interviewed at the start and end of the ten-week session to learn whether they feel they have made gains in the key areas listed above. To this end, students are required to make regular short presentations within the group during the course of the summer, which are assessed by the principal and co-principal investigators. Students are also required to prepare and present their work at a university-wide poster session that typically includes over fifty presenters and hundreds of visitors. Assessment of the quality and relevance of their work is reported by the faculty mentors and collaborators. Finally, students are required to attend and participate in regular professional development seminars and activities that include technical seminars; lab visits and field trips; and exercises on safety, ethics, and leadership skills development that encourage interaction among participants.
